georged

In another thread Lord T brought up an interesting subject, interest rate inversion. Yesterday I walked into a Wal-Mart with the usual S&L placed just
 inside the front entrance and a chalkboard stated '3.8% six-month CD'. With the latest 10-year treasury issue auction 3.99% yield and 2-year at 3.15%, very close to flat, that caught my eye. I came home and looked at futures, 3.7% on 2-year by 2/06, so given a required buffer, 3.8-9 would seem reasonable. I'd think Gamehuis is looking at that to judge equity market earnings as corporate bonds and commercial paper yields will also show increases. 
 
 Has Greenspan stepped on his you know what? His pattern has been .25% increases in the fed rate every three months, now at 3.01, ostentatiously to control inflation, excluding food and energy. Long term treasury offerings have been under-subscribed by the usual players, especially Japan, since the 10/04 election. Europe isn't offering much better due their economic slowdown, which means major players such as China and Japan are mixing their portfolios, hence the reduced demand for long-term US issues. 
 
 Flat and inverted rates have historically signaled an imminent economic recession. Combined with polls indicating substantial public dissatisfaction with US leadership, ultimately reflected in declining consumer confidence in an internal transaction driven economy, I'm concerned that the administration will eventually expand their war to again drive GDP in an attempt to stimulate public and individual spending. Any thoughts?
Dono

I can recall not too many years ago setting aside some "operating" money and placing it in a ladder of treasuries that gave me a flow of cash at intervals with reasonable , safe gain. Looks like the ladder is on the ground now.

I'm watching the possible yield inversion with great interest. Usually inversion is a sign of a slowing economy and possibly recession.
 I've got my finger on the 'short everything' button and am good to go. :p
 
 The only saving grace for the US economy is that this possible inversion will happen with interest rates at relatively low levels, so the hit won't be as bad as the late 80's inversion which was with rates at around 8%.

 At this point it would seem that inflation is a foregone conclusion, and I am not entirely sure that they are going to be able to control it with interest rate hikes. 
 
 Interst rate hikes are an excellent tool for controlling growth and inflaiton in a healthy economy. I think the inflation we are seeing now (and will continue to see int eh future) is th result of the devaluation of the dollar on the currency market. As much as we import, including supply side goods for manufacturing, the weak dollar is killing us. Raising interest rates can certainly help slow the economy, but will result in bad economic numbers, which will drive the dollar even lower, facilitating higher energy costs and import costs, driving the CPI up.
 
 Look at the price of food. On some fresh to market items (milk, lettuce, strawberries, peppers, etc....) prices have doubled in the last 2 years. 
 
 The primary concern of the bush admin seems to be keeping this leaky boat afloat and keeping the american consumer dumb. The longer the population at large can be kept complacent, the more money can be sucked out of them. By the time your average american figures out what the hell happened, it will be over. 
 
 If that means expanding the current war to Iran, they will do it. The american public has proven to be exceptionally gullible about such things. All they (the bushies) need to so is continue their "iranian nuclear weapons are a threat to the entire planet" rhetoric and they can certainly pull it off, with public approval. Another big terrorist attack would virtually gaurante support for such a measure. 
 
 I think the only thing stoppintg them now is that if they have 3 live brain cells between them, they are doubting our bility to win difinitively. Our showing in Iraq has not been stellar.

Interest rate hikes should be able to help control inflation, in the current US situation, 

 
 I idsagree on this one. Interest rate hikes primarily work to control inflation by controlling demand for expansion capitol. Currently, demand for expansion capitol is flat or negative, depending on whose numbers you like. While hiking interest rate may help curb consumer spending (since we are such a debt laden society), I don't think it is likely to curb it enough to matter as far as inflationary control goes. 
 
 
Higher interest rates usually help keep the dollar's valuation up, which should keep the price of imports lower, and slowdown domestic growth, keeping the supply demand firmly on the supply side.

 
 BUT, they really have not helped that much latyely as far as keepign the dollar up. Generally an annoncement of an interst rate hike can send the dollar up from 2.5-4%. Last time, it did not move at all in relation to the hike. It had a short term (5 hour) gain, then settled back down to pre announcement levels. the time before that the gain was only about 1%. Interest rate hiles help boost the dollar because of a perception that rates are going up becuase the fed sees the american economy as robust and growing. Before the last hike, the Japanese finance minister announced that current rate increases were not a sign of a robust economy, but rather a sign that our debt has become so out of control that we can no longer find people willing to purchase it at the low rates. 
 
 If this becomes the new paradigm in the currency market, people taking increased interest rates as a sign of economic weakness as opposed to seeing them as a signal of economic strength, the dollar willl be in for a wild, mostly downward, ride. 
 
 
It is going to require a very fine balancing act, overall I expect a recession to be equal to that of 1987 to occur in the North American market fairly soon

 
 How bad the recession will be, or if we slip into depression, will, I think, be largely decided by the housing bubble. I think there is little doubt when considering the implications of that as a percentage of GDP that serious recession (or more likely, a depression that makes the great depression look like a little recessionary bump) is in order JUST from that. 
 
 the only balancing that I see going on is the balancing of consumer confidence against reality. Keeping the proles ignorant and happy is the primary concern of the party...right?
 
 
 As George has pointed out several times already, without Iraq and associated expenses, we would already be in recession. 
 
 
As a side note Daewoo founder has been taken into custody emoticon_wow

 
 
 I caught that. Apparently their "old boy" network is not substantial enough in korea to protect their own.

 I have been a firm believe in economic cycles especially depressionary ones since high school, when I found a pattern for western Europe and NA of having a depression or serious recession every 50-70 years for the last 300 years or so. We are long over due, and the massive build up in debt in the west is a strong reason to believe that we will have another. The making nice about the 87 recession is not to make people disregard the entire post as being silly.
 
 As for keeping the masses happy and feeling safe is what Greenspan does and does it well. His presence and the confidence in him from many people are keeping the bubble alive.

The consumer spending part is the part I would expect, and as I believe consumer spending is about 60-65% of the US economy, that should help a little. 

 
 I persoanlyl find it doubtful that consumer spending will be significantly effected until interest rates hit above 8%. Already average interest rate for credit cards in the US is 16%. These do not generally fluctuate in response to the base rate, and until individuals see their credit card rates going up significantly they will continue charging their way to a better tomorrow.
 
 Production costs are essentially fixed if you are fighting inflation at the consumer end instead of the production end. As long as production costs increase, there is little that can be done as far as inflationary control. Very few manufacturers have excess profit margins big enough to cut prices substantially enough to drop prices in relation to a lower consumer demand due to inflation. The end effect of all this is likely to be reduced production, leading to unemployment.

We are long over due, and the massive build up in debt in the west is a strong reason to believe that we will have another.  I, too, generally believe in economic cycles. I do not think they are necessarily set in stone. They are instead idicitive of how long it takes us as a society to forget the mistakes and lessons of the past. There is not a whole lot of new stuff going on here. Lessons learned during the stock market crash that led to the great depression can easily be applied to our current situation regarding the housing (or dare I say real estate) bubble. What is history if not the documentation of people making the same predictable mistakes repeatedly?

The consumer spending part is the part I would expect, and as I believe consumer spending is about 60-65% of the US economy, that should help a little. If and when China and the other Asian economies decide to stop propping up the dollar no amount of interest rate hikes will stop the dollar decline.

 
 Here's 2004 US GDP composition:
 
 19% Government 
 70% Personal consumption
 16% Investment
 10% Exports
 -15% imports
 
 One reason this administration prefers a declining USD is to make numbers. That decline creates monetary inflation, expanding GDP numbers, encouraging consumer confidence.
 
 Looking at the total of 89% government and consumer spending and acknowledging the amount of credit (public and personal) and payment imbalance used to facilitate those numbers provides a simple picture; the only major issues in continued expansion being ability to service debt and continued consumer confidence. When combined with a declining tax base and badly crippled manufacturing sector, that's about as shaky an economic structure as I can imagine. 
 
 As you point out, when China (now the driving force behind Asian development and whom Japan is betting some serious chips on) raises their per-capita income to reduce western export capability by domestic consumption, supporting the USD will no longer be a major priority. And if USD 
 isn't required, 25% interest rates won't sell treasury securities. 
 
 With China's patience and considering it'll be another five plus years before reaching that point of per-capita income, IMO the big question is how long the US economy can sustain consumer confidence. The fact that sort-term interest rates are catching long-term rates is not a sign of confidence in the future.
lord tammerlain

http://atimes.com/atimes/Global_Economy/GF16Dj01.html
 
 
This was precisely what Greenspan did in the 1990s in the name of preemptive measures against inflation. Dollar hegemony enabled the US to print money to fight inflation, causing a debt bubble of asset appreciation. These data substantiated the view of the US as Rome in a New Roman Empire with an unending stream of imports as the free tribute from conquered lands. This was what Greenspan meant by US "financial hegemony". 
 
 The Fed Funds Rate (FFR)target has been lifted eight times in steps of 25 basis points from 1% in mid-2004 to 3% on May 3, 2005. If the same pattern of "measured pace" continues, the FFR target would be at 4.25% by the end of 2005. Despite Fed rhetoric, the lifting of dollar interest rates has more to do with preventing foreign central banks from selling dollar-denominated assets, such as US Treasuries, than with fighting inflation. In a debt-driven economy, high interest rates are themselves inflationary. Raising interest rates to fight inflation could become the monetary dog chasing its own interest-rate tail, with rising rates adding to rising inflation, which then requires more interest-rate hikes. Still, interest-rate policy is a double edged sword: it keeps funds from leaving the debt bubble, but it can also puncture the debt bubble by making the servicing of debt prohibitively expensive.
 This is part of the balancing act that Greenspan has to maintain
 

 To prevent this last adverse effect, the Fed adds to the money supply, creating an unnatural condition of abundant liquidity with rising short-term interest rates, resulting in a narrowing of interest spread between short-term and long-term debts, a leading indication for inevitable recession down the road. The problem of adding to the money supply is what John Maynard Keynes called the liquidity trap, that is, an absolute preference for liquidity even at near-zero interest-rate levels. Keynes argued that either a liquidity trap or interest-insensitive investment draft could render monetary expansion ineffective in a recession. It is what is popularly called pushing on a credit string, where ample money cannot find creditworthy willing borrowers. Much of the new low-cost money tends to go to refinancing existing debt taken out at previously higher interest rates. Rising short-term interest rates, particularly at a measured pace, would not remove the liquidity trap while long-term rates stay flat because of excess liquidity. 
 
 The debt bubble in the US is clearly having problems, as evident in the bond market. With just 14 deals worth $2.9 billion, May 2005 was the slowest month for high-yield bond issuance since October 2002. The late-April downgrades of the debt of General Motors and Ford Motor to junk status roiled the bond markets. The number of high-yield, or junk-bond, deals fell 55% in the March-to-May 2005 period compared with the same three months in 2004. They were also down 45% from the December-through-February period. In dollar value, junk-bond deals totaled $17.6 billion in the March-to-May 2005 period, compared with $39.5 billion during the same three months in 2004 and $36 billion from December 2004 through February 2005. There were 407 deals of investment-grade bond underwriting during the March-to-May 2005 period, compared with 522 in the same period 2004 - a decline of 22%. In dollar volume, some $153.9 billion of high-grade bonds were underwritten from March to May 2005, compared with $165.5 billion in the same period in 2004 - a 7% decline.

The transition to offshore outsourced production has been the source of the productivity boom of the "New Economy" in the US in the past decade. The productivity increase not attributable to the importing of other nations' productivity is much less impressive. While published government figures of the productivity index show a rise of nearly 70% since 1974, the actual rise is between zero and 10% in many sectors if the effect of imports  is removed from the equation. The lower productivity values are consistent with the real-life experience of members of the blue-collar working class and the white-collar middle class who have been spending the equity cash-outs from the appreciated market value of their homes

 Our (US) strongest industry is mass residential housing, which is already displaying initial signs of unraveling from higher interest rates. That'll take several months for the spending reductions to filter down through through associated entities, producing credit card delinquencies and eventually mortgage defaults. I look at early-middle summer for full impact on retailers, including the US vehicle industry. As 32% of US lumber, a even larger amount of synthetic building products and a large portion of our energy requirements are now imported from Canada, our situation will impact Canada on the export side. You payment balance will absorb a great deal of that, but it will cost jobs until those products can be redirected to other consumers.
 
 The big issue in my mind is potential US recovery from a recession. We no longer have an industrial base capable of attracting capital to generate new wealth and administration has based all domestic and foreign policy on a very expensive, condemned war of aggression during times of declining tax base and abnormal deficit spending. Any thoughts on recovery?
